content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Your popularity...*Dramatic pause*IS RISING!Update:Wow, I honestly never imagined that this joke would reach the lengths it did. I suppose this justifies an actual review.Welcome to Stronghold Crusader, a game I picked up at a whim when I was 12 (actually have about 1,000 hours clocked in the disc version of the game; I was sheltered from Steam for a long time). I had, at the time, no idea what the game was about, I just knew that I was a huge medieval era fan and decided the game looked pretty cool. Trust me though, no matter of sweet, sweet disc cover could have prepared me for the fungasm that was Stronghold Crusader. Lets move on to an actual review now.Stronghold Crusader is an RTS (real-time strategy) game based on the First, Second, and Third Crusade, not to mention the conflicts within Crusader states. As with all RTS', this means that you will have control of armies, workers, not to mention fortification and building construction in an attempt to outwit your opponent and kill their king. However, Stronghold does this better than even most current-generation RTS', in my opinion, including games like Starcraft 2. It's hard for me to come up with a "pros and cons" list, because for me, this game doesn't have any cons; difficulty is to be expected as you progress in time spent in-game. Let me spend a little time bulleting what is so attractive about this game.-There is a multitude of units. You've got your various siege equipment (battering rams, catapults, trebuchets, you name it), melee units with their own unique advantages, ranged units similarly, various traps, MOATS (that's right nerdy kid who loves castles, moats), and chances are you will end up using every single one of these characters at some point during the game; which leads to my next point.-No two games are alike. Before anyone corrects me, I'm aware that there are (always have been) certain strategies to try and end games quickly; slave rushing; mercenary armies in early game, etc. That being said, these strategies are not always reliable and will leave you resourceless. The fact is that you are probably going to need a different strategy for each game you play, ESPECIALLY in multiplayer.-The game itself is rich in history, which I personally find fascinating. The single player campaign will have you drilling your way through multiple missions; these missions are based off the real accounts of the First, Second, and Third Crusades, as well as the intergroup struggles that grew in that time. You will command armies in historic battles like the Siege of Jerusalem, Heraclea, and Krak des Chevaliers. All this is accompanied by what I find to be a stellar set of voice actors and most likely the best squire a king could ever ask for creates an almost life-like representation of the era. You know what, the squire gets his own bullet.-The squire; this awesome individual is your in-game guide/cheerleader/father-figure. If you play the game, you WILL learn to love him. The squire is a non-physical character who informs you of how you are doing, whether you are under attack, or if you are out of resources. He will sit and shout in your ear "WOOD NEEDED" or "THE GRANARY STOCKS ARE FULL, M'LORD." -Resource management. While not really a new feature to RTS', the resource management in this game will force you to think steps ahead of your opponent, or suffer the consequences; every resource is expendable. "Not enough stone to build your walls? Buy some from the trade post for gold, or trade your other resources to get that precious stone. Beware, though, trade too much of one resource and it may dry up and your stocks will quickly be depleted, which means you are screwed when it comes to anything that requires that resource.-Multiplayer. This is where 90% of my horus playing this game went. I could sit here and rant onward about all of my games where I had almost lost, but like the underdog of the story, I prevailed!However, I won't; as a matter of fact, I will make this really simple: take every bulletpoint I've created, and imagine what it'd be like to face another person. The campaign missions may not necessarily be the most difficult, but the multiplayer is where I am convinced Army strategists should be trained for real-life duty. How you act in a game, every move you make, every resource you spend/use, will affect the outcome and decide whether you are truly the king of the land, or whether you are a lonely peasant, not fit to lick the boot of your opponent.TL;DR:Despite not being the most "relevant" entry in the RTS genre, Stronghold Crusader still manages to remain an idol to be followed for other RTS games. If you are truly skipping my beautifully composed points above, just know that the game is wonderful. For the price it's listed at now, I would say you are criminally insane to not buy it."Do you recommend this game?" Steam asks.My response? "Of course, m'lord!"

Posted: September 27, 2015
												If anyone ever asked me what was my favorite game as a kid, it would be Stronghold Crusader hand down. Today I keep it on steam to leave my old disc on the shelf as a momento of my childhood. SC is a classic with the perfect balance of light hearted castle sim charm and rts combat. Ive dumped easily 1000 hours into random skirmish matches against the ai lords over the years and this is one game that I can always turn back to at any time to pass 20 minutes to 2 hours and always have a good time. Learning how to balance your economy to support troop creation has a very mild learning curve but it takes time to master but yet is simple enough for even a 1st grader to learn as I did when I first started playing this game in 2001.This game has aged exceptionally well and still has an active multiplayer community because anyone that ever took a bite of this game knows just how good it really is. I strongly reccommend this game to add to your collection as an old fan or a newby looking for a new toy to reignite your passion for gaming all over again. Overall, I would rate this title 11/10 as it really is a unicorn in the PC gaming realm. Thank you

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
An old masterpiece came to Steam - in High Definition (or atleast high resolution...)I remember, when I was a little boy about 9 years old, I saw this game in a market and I begged my dad to buy me this RTS-game. I played everyday and it was never boring - not even a little bit! And now it is here - on Steam! Feeling the satisfaction of building your own castle while at the same time demolishing someone else's. Just. Great.to the m'lord-cave!++ best "Stronghold"++ it's a classic+ one of the best RTS (in my opinion!)+ 16 different enemies with special tactics!+ many maps (whether balanced or not)+ historical missions+ 2 campaigns (2nd campaign is much harder!)+ skirmish mode! (80 missions)+ different modes: the peaceful and war path+ loads of playable options+ create your own maps!+ easy gameplay and easy to learn the mechanics+ no food? no fear! - beer is here!+ and it won't get boring - only harder :)+ you don't need a high-end gamer ultra 4k PC"buildings are in flames m'lord!"- HD? Just the resolution changed- ma' crusade ended 1781 AC (depends on how long you play)- AI won't build armies over 400 soldiers- The Kalif is an as*hole- what year is it?- campaign is less "personal" - got killed by 100 slaves- often you can easily rush the enemy in the first minutes- double rations- some people can't run the game! (you are warned)A little extra information: in "Stronghold Crusader Extreme" you are able to build armies up to 10000 soldiers... and the enemy too ;-)just an information if you would complain about the limited army size, like I mentioned before :-)Those negative aspects are just poop, so don't mention them.I can tell that you WILL have lot of fun. I'm through the first 50 missions and already at 35 hours! You don't need a sale to buy this, just 8€ and you recieve hours of fun. Don't mind the graphics, it's from 2002! But remember - This is a recommendation for Stronghold Crusader and not for the whole series (sadly the game became more and more worse)."Do you recommend this game?"- "Of course, m'lord!" 9/10little update: I am through the 100 missions of the crusade and have about ~60 hours playtime (because of connection problems, my counted hours are false)... and I didn't even started the real campaign :-DI think if you play every mission, campaign and possible option you can reach 100 hours!Some people have the problem that the game doesn't start at all - maybe this thread can help you: http://steamcommunity.com/app/40970/discussions/0/361787186433062259/

Posted: November 28, 2013
												This game is a classic, I remember playing the demo sometime back in like, early 2002...? Can't really remember, but even today it holds great quality for a game this old. Graphics are obviously quite dated, but considering that the game was acctualy released in 2002 they arn't THAT bad, infact they are quite impressive and back in 2002 they were most likely very high standards. The gameplay is excellent, watching battles between 2 factions are just incredible. 500-600 men fighting for victory. The AI is smart and very, very different depening on which settings you play on. Some AI are REALLY slow whilst others are REALLY fast. This is both good and bad but it will keep you entertained for a good time. What makes this game so entertaining is that you must always keep your economy, troop producment, and other vital producments above your opponent. If not, you will most likely lose.The only REAL flaw with this game is that it has ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s of glitches, and the AI can sometime get stuck when they build their castle.8/10

number of helpful: 37 of 39 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												There's nothing much like building a huge empire castle with seemingly undefetable defenses, and than it all falls apart just because your friend was one step ahead of you the whole time building his army of tens of thousands of men to take down your castle. Stronghold Crusader HD delivers this on every level. This game and I go way back, to 2006, My brother chose this game as a game that he wanted to buy from Target. At first I hated this game, mostly because I didn't try it. After I did try it one rainy day I fell in love with it. It does take a little bit to learn everything, but once you do it is one of the most addicting and fact paced Stragety games of all time!PROS:+ Simple but nice graphics: Sure they aren't amazing, but it has a disctinct art style that does help make you feel more a part of that world.+ Amazing strategic gameplay, It lures you in by seeming to be simple with a decent+The voice acting AWFUL, but it is the kind of awful that you and your friends can have a good hearty laugh at, and of course the quotes with the "voice actors" deliver really helps make this game feel all its own and have it's entirely own feeling to it.+ Fun Characters: the characters have their own personalities, and while some are addmitedly one note (the pig is fat GET IT!?) It adds more that subtracts from the experiance.+Great Map Selection (Some very basic ones and some really interesting ones, over 20! (Over 100 if you look at just the skirmish ones [Although I do belive they are exclusive to skirmish which I would like to see changed and probally there is a way to do it manually] And of coruse, you can make your own.)+ A ton of Gameplay types. There is, Custom Map Maker, 4 (or 4+) Campaigns, 3 (Including the Extreme Expansion) Trials (Which are linked matches between you and a bot, there are 50 on the original one. 30 on the Warchest one and 20 on the Extreme Trails) But, there is a major problem with the extreme trials (as of 12/30/13) it starts you at the final one for some reason) and of coruse Skirmish Mode (You can play what map you want with either friends, or solo and choose teams and such. oh and one more thing, Castle Sim Mode is just like Skirmish Mode, but without the batltes. ))+Fantastic Music! It is not only atmospheric but can also be catchy as hell and sounds natural helping the imersion of the game by a boatload! The game even changes music depending on the situation you are in, are you getting bombarded by a bunch of spear men? Then the game will switch to an intense battle song and fade out as soon as you (hopefull) defeat the spearmen. +The netcode is HIGHLY improoved in my experiances to the original, back in the original every game would be pleagued by the infamous "Connection lost, sending current game state" message, however  if I do ever encounter it in this version it dissapears in a split second!+This version is compatable with the original! So, if your friends computer can't handle the brand new resolution just install the CD version and you can play with the HD version (with GameRanger of course!) and this helps blend the line between the Steam players and the CD Players. The same can not be said about AOE2 HD or RON:EXE.+The game runs great on all types of hardware, from my ancient (Basically) 2010 Notebook to my modern computer (which I am writing this review with) and even my Aspire R14, the game runs without a hitch and surprisingly has minimal compatibility glitches [Not including the ones that were there]CONS:+Troops sometimes ignore orders, or take a while to do them. Sometimes you will tell it to do something and they will just wonder off which gets annoying especially in the heat of battle.+It's sometimes hard to see close into your castle with the brand new resolution, it would be nice if you could zoom into the map even further.+Some AI share the same animations (most notably, The Rat and the Wolf if you have them on your team.+Some Animation's are choppy (The blacksmith preview goes at about 20 frames)+When you zoom out all the way the FPS halves.+The AI is awful. They rarley (if ever) change up their attacks and do the same thing over and over again. Some AI is over protective making invading their castle a hastle [hahaha! GET IT!] to a point where I just save the game, quit, and never return to that saved game. +Balancing Issues: Little problems that they are you may have to (atleast in multiplayer) turn on the No Rush timer as to not allow people to bombard your castle with Assassins which are not only fast, invisible (unless nearing your men), and strong, but they also have a surprisingly large health bar which makes killing them annoying as they mow down even your strongest men and take out your king (how you loose) without a problem as early as the first few minutes. [They fixed this in the 2nd Game however that is a whole different can of worms.]+No proper Steamworks Multiplayer support, you must download a game client like GameRanger (which isn't bad, just inconvenient] +Awful expansion. Stronghold Crusader HD Extreme is the included expansion and adds some fantastic stuff [Maps, campaigns, 8 new AI Characters] but sadly starts to support castle hiding where you hide everyone inside your castle and let you generate stuff (yes this expansion adds a Mana styled magic bar that lets you create stuff and destroy your enemies castle with flying rocks that you spawn) which sounds badass. However, it throws all balancing and fairness out the window. Anyone can click on the rocks and click on the enemy castle to demolish it and make it ripe for the conquest, however what Stronghold Crusader HD (The base game) strives on is the ability to conquest the castle using your men that you build up which makes it imsenly more satisfying and more fair to put it bluntly.+Glitches. The main one that I am talking about is when you launch SC:HD Extreme for the first time and you go to the skirmish mission you get the due honor of skipping directly to the last level for no apparent reason, effectivly making the previous 20 or so missions useless. Overall:Even in the ripe year of 2016 Stronghold Crusader HD has surprisingly aged well. The problems (Some miniscule others annoying) really don't distract from the overall experiance as much as one may think. The PROS FAR outweigh the CONS in this situation and makes Stronghold Crusader HD (even with the Flawed Extreme expansion) a great time that is easily worth the 9.99 asking price. And even if you don't feel confortable about paying that much it goes on sale for down to 5 dollars sometimes so keep an eye out because I assure you, its a game that you will need to see to believe. [In a good way]If you enjoyed this review you should check out my fellow reviewers at  Completing the Backlog Edit: And hey this game has some great uses for cows...

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend Stronghold Crusader skip to Results and read from there.Firefly Studies strikes again with the best Stronghold game in the series. Stronghold Crusader is a brilliant game that mixes Castle Simulation with RTS combat, and resource management. Story:As the title depicts Stronghold Crusader takes place in the Crusades. You play through the Asia minor, The Middle East, as Europeans and Arabians alike. The story takes place across four campaigns where you start your journey as Emporer Alexus of the Turkish Army commands you to take ahold of Asia Minor. You spread European influence across the land, but it is short lived as the Salidan rises to power and destroys the settlements of the Europeans and claims back the lands. Unfortunately for him the crusades were not over, and the Germanic armies arrive deploying castles across Asia minor as they claim lay to the holy lands. Stronghold Crusader takes place across the first to third crusades and then creates an alternate reality that is the post-crusade wars that pit you against your worst nightmare: The Rat, The Snake, The Pig, and The Wolf. Campaign:Stronghold Crusader has four campaigns which teach you how to play the game from the basics to the most advanced.The Call to ArmsCall to Arms offers five basic missions which although simple are in fact challenging in their own rights. The first mission encompasses basic castle siege, the second basic defense, the third resource management, the fourth resource massing, and the final one a more complicated castle siege. This campaign is a great way to start into the Stronghold Series as it introduces the elements of gameplay in an interesting way that keeps you entertained. Typical tutorials are rather uninteresting, but Call to Arms changes that by providing dynamic missions that introduce the game with diverse scenarios. Saladin’s ConquestAfter the conquest of Call to Arms you pick up the campaign as Salidan who is retaking the land stolen by the Europeans. All the missions in Salidan’s Conquest are sieges; these involve taking castles from the enemy. All of Salidans missions are rather simple, yet offer diversity in how you conquer your foe. You are limited on units and must use unique units to push through the enemy defenses. The Kings CrusadeAfter the Salidan has kicked out most of Europe the quest continues as the third crusade picks up and its up to the Europeans to hold off their fortresses from the Salidans onslaughts. The Kings Crusade mostly focuses on castle building and defense, similar to Mission 4 of The Call to Arms. Each level provides new features which give you a better mechanism to defend you castle and equip you against an ever stronger foe until you eventually must siege castle and rebuild it from the ground up. Crusader StatesThe campaign begins after the third crusade and is a fictitious rendition of what we expected after the Third Crusade ended. You play in the Middle East as lord’s squalor over various lands and it is up to you to defeat your foes. Your mission through the Middle East pits you against the foes of the past: The Rat, The Snake, The Pig, and The Wolf. The further you get into the campaign the more enemies you get pit against. Gameplay:Stronghold Crusader is noted as being the best Stronghold game; it took what was good from the original and expanded upon it beautifully. Stronghold Crusader is a castle simulation game, where you manage a castle politically, economically, and sociologically. You must maintain various food types, keep your people happy, while simultaneously ripping them dry for every penny they have. You need to build a well-oiled machine, but unlike most strategy games Stronghold has many resources. To build units you must obtain gold, you must build their weapons, you must provide peasant, you must feed them with various food stocks, and you must obtain the resources required to build those weapons. For all of this to occur you must keep peasants within your castle by making sure they are happy, once they start to leave your castle will crumble from within before your enemies even hit your walls. Stronghold Crusader takes that and incorporates mercenaries, units which cost gold and require less work to obtain. Of course they cost almost triple that of a non-hired unit, but offer quick turn-around. Not only did they add mercenaries, but they included Skirmishes with AI, which allow you to play the game without playing the campaign. The AI is rather intelligent and will keep you on your toes, and not only that but the maps are designed to require intense combat. This game will make you fight over limited agrarian land and low wood stocks. Hints:>When you start a map drop the gamespeed to 20, this gives you loads of time to set yourself up before the match really begins.>When playing the crusader states the game gives you sometimes up to 7.5k gold, if you drop the game-speed to 20 and place a market you can buy Maces and Leather Armor. Then quickly build an army of Macemen to take out your foes before the match can even begin. This does not work on all missions, but certainly helps.>Bread is the easiest food to build-up. If you are trying to optimize limited farmland use wheat as its easy to mass. Results:Stronghold Crusader is the best castle simulation game out there right now. It offers the joy of castle simulation with the intensities of combat. I would recommend this game to anyone who is thinking about taking part in the Stronghold Series, it’s a great place to start as it will pull you right in. Stronghold Crusader is a fantastic game for castle simulation fans and real time strategy fans alike. I would recommend this buying this game even at full price, but if you can get it at a discount its worth every penny and you won’t regret it. Pros:+Four amazing campaigns which teach you how to play the game without being boring or repetitive.+The AI has various levels of intelligence which makes them fun as well as challenging.+They added mercenaries which allow you to build emergency armies quick, but cost extraordinary sums of gold. +Finally Skirmishes have been introduced; you don’t have to play the campaign or multiplayer. You can just mess around by yourself. +New strategic limitations, such as limited grass for agriculture which makes you consider your strategies.Cons:-I couldn’t minimize the game; it would minimize but not maximize (Windows 8.1)-When playing you could not open steam overlay, one of the commands for steam overlay is a command for the games GUI display.

content:
Posted: April 4
												My first strategy-type game I have ever played in my childhood. This is where my thirst and hunger for winning started. This may not be for people that are playing a game and evaluating it from a graphical side. It is 2002 game, so.. In my opinion it is pretty strategic and fun to play.My first time that I had to play this game was horrible, because I had absolutelly no logic (Yes, you need to have brain to play this game. This is not just building and done). What I was doing back then just building beautiful buildings, such as church and etc. I didn't know what I was doing. So, when I grew up, I got into this game out of nostalgia. I understood what I was doing at that time, and it was lmao to remember what I was doing back there... xDSo, as I said, this game needs logic, because you are not going to survive and win by doing random♥♥♥♥♥♥ You start up in different locations of the map with your opponents and you the point is to build your castle, make troops and protect yourself and slaughter them. But the most logical part of the game, is management of resources. Gold, stone, wood, food, iron. Nothing complicated. The food is the most essential resource for surviving obviously. Without it, people will leave your castle and you have nothing... So after you have dispatched resource income in appriopriate way and value, you have to build up you castle (That's my favourite part, because you can build in any way you want) and protect it, because everything is risky. They can target your resource income building, which can leave you empty and put you at a disadvantage. Thinking through stuff, and protecting everything is the key. After building up stage, some obviously will choose to attack, and some of them will have to defend. Defending is the most fun part, because after you dispatched your troops at appropriate locatons of defense (such as towers) for protection, it is so satisfying to see how strong is your defense, and after that you can find your weakness. Then, it is up to you, you build up your army, you slaughter, you win. That's all. Also there are campaign and other modes which can give a little bit of a challenge against other opponents. Some stages will be hard, and will give you a location with disadvantages, but it is up to you how you will build up, survive, destroy and win.That I think is everything to this game. I recommend it for players that are interested in strategic. (Bu I am guessing there are people who have started their journey from this one and what I mean is that they already tried it).

number of helpful: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												A lot of sequels strike out in new directions, and end up falling flat for their trouble. Sometimes they get too far away from what made the original great, and other times they find a way to ruin that original appeal. The other side of the coin is that just giving players more of the original risks making the series stale. This is the approach that Stronghold Crusader took in the wake of Stronghold's success, but the sheer volume of content more than makes up for the lack of innovation.Just as you did in Stronghold, Crusader challenges you to erect and manage castles throughout a variety of scenarios and skirmishes. Once your keep and granary are placed, it's up to you to site farms, mills, workshops, and homes to keep your people safe and happy. So long as you remain a popular ruler more people will come serve at your castle, but more people means a greater drain on your resources. In the midst of balancing these two factors you'll need to raise walls and armies to fend off invaders seeking your crown.The familiar moors of England have given way to the marauding Moors of the holy land for this outing. There are a few big changes to be aware of, most notably the desert maps. Gone are the rolling fields of the first game, instead leaving you with small oases to supply your essential farms and woodcutters. A mercenary post allows you to recruit new Arabian units, everything from armored swordsmen to wall-scaling assassins. There's even a rudimentary diplomacy system, allowing you to form alliances and request resources.Stronghold Crusader features four historical campaigns, focusing on different parts of the Crusades. Each campaign is five scenarios long and features a gentle learning curve that provides a fair challenge by the end. There's little story to be found here in contrast with Stronghold's tale of political maneuvering, just some blurbs about historical relevance. The real meat of the game is the Crusader mode, a campaign of up to 50 battles against AI opponents. Right from the get-go you can access all the buildings and options the game has to offer in pursuit of conquest, building your perfect citadel and laying siege to nearby enemies. The strategy of castle-to-castle warfare takes a little getting used to after the easy pace of the campaigns, but it's thrilling to launch pitched battles and deploy siege engines to topple your foes.There's not a lot of innovation to be found here over the original Stronghold, but there really doesn't need to be. Crusader instead gives you plenty more to see and do, especially on the military side. The graphics are a bit improved, with sharper structures and cleaner animations, and the sounds of both peace and battle are just as immersive as before. Honestly, I consider this the superior game just due to the depth of content and the little additions to the proven formula. If you're looking for endless conquest and sieges, this is the Stronghold title you want.

number of helpful: 13 of 13 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												Stronghold: Crusader is an RTS (real time strategy) game based in the Middle East during the Crusades, namely mainly in the third. Some parts of the game, however, take place before that. It's a kind of extension of the game Stronghold, which Crusader in many aspects resembles, but Stronghold is set in medieval England.Stronghold: Crusader is Stronghold enriched with new mechanics, the most famous of these is the Skirmish mode, the heart of the game. It is a mode in which each player or computer opponent has one base on a map and they must develop, market, prosper and build castles and defense. Since all players are on one map, they can interact with each other, whether it's positively or negatively. Allies can trade with each other, defend each other and attack together. The game goal is most of the time to kill all the enemy Lords and not die in the process. The game balances the economy and the war very well. The player must develop their economy through taxes, food rations, trade and so on. They must seek to balance their popularity to not become unpopular, because in that case people will begin to leave the castle and it will severely impede the player's progress. If the player has a good economy, they can take up making a great army, which is usually quite costly. This is the way the game balances the economy and the war, and I like it. You should think about your tactics and castle management a bit and not just rush into war straight away - otherwise you go to your knees, whether you like it or not.The main objectives of the game itself are the 2 Skirmish trails. They consist of a number of consecutive Skirmishes. In each mission the player has certain enemies, sometimes allies, a set map and everyone's position on it, and a set amount of money and resources. There are 16 PC enemies altogether and about 80 maps (citation needed), so with such diversity there is also an option to play your own game, where the player chooses the map, their allies and adversaries as well as everyone's money and resources. Computer opponents are also quite diverse: 6 Arab and 10 Crusader leaders, each of whom has different castles, different tactics, different personalities, and there's a lot to the game to keep you interested long enough.In addition to Skirmish trails, one can play historical campaigns. They're based on specific historical periods and events during the Crusades. They are there to teach the player the game. The first campaign teaches the fundamentals of the economy, defense and siege. The second campaign teaches the player how to use unique Arab units. In the third campaign the player learns to defend against them, and the fourth campaign is already full-on Skirmish mode. In the first three campaigns the player doesn't have the Skirmish mode freedom because they either defend against attacks at certain intervals, while trying to achieve a set goal (Defend Antioch! Gather 300 loaves of bread!, and the like), while they often don't have access to all buildings - or they get a certain number of soldiers with which to conquer a city. This is exactly why a lot of people find these campaigns boring, tedious and difficult. In a sense they are right. These campaigns are fine, but cumbersome unlike the rest of the game. The game also includes a mode of free castle building without enemies, map editor and LAN multiplayer for 8 players.Crusader Extreme added a bar of (super)powers, which fills up slowly and over time unlocks the abilities for your use - such as a rain of arrows or rocks on a specific place on the map. It also added military outposts - buildings that relatively slowly generate troops for free. This allows all PC adversaries to be stronger than normal - for example the Rat, the weakest adversary, suddenly gets a huge army of swordsmen, pikemen, horse archers and seven catapults - and they're coming for you!Overall, I think that Stronghold: Crusader is an excellent game. Fun and fast paced with minor weak points and bugs, which can be overlooked. 9/10PS: The Steam version doesn't cooperate with Steam firefly fix pls

												A fun and nostalgic game. Brings back some fine memories from childhood.There are some bugs however that makes some campaign maps unplayable. After playing some maps for a while the game speed gets locked on the slowest speed and it can't be changed regardless of what game speed i choose. number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Looking for a good RTS? Look no Further.This game is the pinnacle of quality for the Stronghold series. The first game lacks the depth that Crusader has, but is still very good. Problem is that every game after this one, in the Stronghold series, just doesn't measure up. This game has a perfect blend of complexity and simplicity.The game isn't so complicated that its hard to pick up or understand, but not so simple that there is a lack of depth.Likewise the play of the game is balanced between economics/resources management and Military strategy. In some other RTS games it is absolutely true that whoever can rush their economy the fastest is the victor, and I would say that is not the case for this game. Speed is of course an important factor, but unless one player is particularly slow in comparision to the other, speed will not be the deciding factor. The ability you have for using your economy to maximize your military potential through any number of means, as well as your ability to strategically use your troops/resources to take advantage of your opponent's weaknesses are the most important factors.However, understanding your map placement while using this in your overall strategy, and your ability to build/defend your castle are extremely important. A player near less resources with a weaker economy can play more defensively, defeat an opponent's army who lays siege, and then counter attack before the opponent can recover from the losses to pull a victory. Or in the same scenario, the player in a weak spot can harass with the goal to destroy their opponent's economy, thus crippling them, then pressing the advantage. The ways a game can be played and won are vast.Multiplayer is where this depth of gameplay becomes most visible, but due to the direct IP connect multiplayer set up it is easiest to just use a service with lobbies to set up games with randoms. I recommend Game Ranger. The community isn't huge, but is still large enough that it isn't hard to find someone online to play with.From my perspective, this is the greatest RTS of all time.Keeping my personal bias aside, this game is very good, especially for it's time.I believe it is an under appreciated title worth picking up for it's price.TL;DR : Graphics are okay, not confusing or hard to look at, but not stunning due to their age.Gameplay is not without it's flaws, but it is in depth and the application of strategy, awareness, and quick thinking are key. Making use of European and/or Arabic units is also an important element.Multiplayer is fun and much more in depth than playing with bots, but its better to use an external program for matchmakingModes; there are a few to choose from, Multiplayer, custom game mode, there is custom map making which can be shared with other players in multiplayer, Single player has two crusader trails which set you up against bots in specific set ups, and a historical single player mode where you defend real crusader castles like Kerak de Chevaliers.Sounds/Soundtrack nothing I would write home about, but its not hard to listen to either.Should you read this review, and then decide to buy this game and thenwant to get in on multiplayer, feel free to add me.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Stronghold Crusader came out mid 2002 after the succesful Stronghold in 2001. Stronghold Crusader is set in the Middle East during the crusades rather then Europe like the first one, hence the name Crusader. This is a real time stratergy game with the focus of killing the enemy Lord/s. Careful though as he will be very strong and can take over 10000 archer arrows! don't worry it is done on purpose so you can kill him at a range, so best to send 10 plus swords men at him.If you played the Original like I did many moons ago there are changes in this HD edition and NONE! are bad. There are 8 more characters to verus, more resolution sizes and graphics has imporved. Everything else is the same as the original which is amazing!So the Pro's:- Personally the best out of all Strongholds- Unique RTS that requires not only military stratergies but also civil (do you make them drunk and fed or starve and whip them?)- Arabian units are an awesome edition giving alot more unit choice- Fire implementation in the game is great, see random guys on fire turn a city into a flame ball (happens more often then you think), yes this is a pro!!- Large campaign and a few side stories 'missions'- Great to plan with mates (LAN or over the net)- Replayability in custom maps or make your own which is easily shared to other pc's when trying to match make- alot of challanging Lords to play- Fun castle building and designing to fit all military and civil works in and aroundCon's- 400 unit pop count, may sound like alot but it isn't when you are trying to kill 7 Lord's at once- The Large map for 8 Players can seem very small in most instances- If AI Lords placed close together or near iron it is create holes or even block themsleves in starving their kingdom.- No unit or building healing (can repair towers and that's it)- Would be good to make AI even harder, they have Lords to difficulty but it would be good if you can adjust it more- Most of the time units will not attack the enemy until they are either told or the enemy are already bashing their face in- Enemy AI with their army can be very disorganized making them easy preyOverall I love this edition of Stronghold Crusader HD, I will continue to use it and LAN with friends. If you want a LAN game to kill some time this is great for you! (better to vs your friends for more of a challange).any questions don't be afriad to ask.

content:
Posted: February 13
												'Ahhh Running out of tax again, fetch me the tax collector!'-The SherrifI don't have many hours on steam, but besides from steam i probably have hundreds of hours into this game. It doesn't have the flashy graphics from nowadays but the gameplay and the depht is amazing. Every A.I. Character has it's own strenghts and weaknesses. From the Rat being mid game downright anyoing because of his infinite units spams of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ economically devastating units if he breaches your defences somehow, to the mighty Wolf with his almost impenatrable castles and huge armies which will decimate you and your allies if not prepared for them. This game is the living proof you can live on beer and relgion or flowers and graves. If your popularity is down and you don't have food, just build some churches and taverns and lets get drunk with god. It might be a hard game to get at first but after you've played a couple of games and watched some vids you will get it and become better.It doesn't have a main campaign, instead it has several smaller campaign of 5 missions each. next to these missions are the trials in which you must fight every lord with and without allies and with an econimical disadvantage and an ally disadvantage. The game is balanced because everyone has access to the same units. some maps might not be balanced but thats what gives you the challenge.This is downright the best game of the developer. the games following this title aren't as good espacially stronghold 3 which is a turd. If you want hours of gameplay for not to much money, this is your game to play.(tip buy collectors edition from steam in a sale or from a third party site)

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												After all those years Stronghold Crusader did not get old. It is entertaining as it was years ago and by getting HD version it looks better on modern PC screens.The most important things I'd like to recommend are: balanced gameplay; interesting and long single player campaign; multiplayer mode; good AI of enemies controlled by computer; great soundtrack; oldschool (but in a positive way!) graphic; user-friendly mechanics. It also runs smooth. I know the game's old, but I remember it was good optimized years ago and now, on modern computers, it still runs well.What else to say? This game is a game of a high quality, definitely. If you haven't played it yet then you should, because Stronghold Crusader is truly one of the best RTS games ever made (at least in my oppinion).

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
 Game is on sale, should I buy it?  If you like strategy games or stronghold games atall then yes. Easily worth the sale price. Should you buy this game?  Yes!! This was the strategy game of my childhood and still is. The game plays well and has a good economy and combat which means you will always be fighting or be close to action most of the game. (Obvious some exceptions 1v1 on largest map `-`) The game plays the same as the other Stronghold games but has a different food system where you can only have farms on grass. Take note the game is set in the desert. Skirmish mode is where the game shines since the AI is decent in giving you a challenge especially when you are against the odds. Obvious flaws in the AI play style exist but doesn't affect the game at all. I've had hours before buying the steam version and will probally sink some more in when I can. There is a good map variety and a decent amount of AI characters each with 2-3 different set castles they build and each have their own playstyle and unit variety. There isn't a difficulty slider for the AI apart from gold they start. Is there a campaign? No. There is not a set campaign like other strongholds. The missions are just skirmish battles but pre set. There are roughly 30 of these in base game and 30 in expansion which is included in this. (I havn't played or counted all of these so don't hold me to numbers) These get more challenging and make some interesting battles if you get half way through. Is this worth it over the non HD version? Technically no. All this adds is resolution support which makes it run somewhat more smoothly but doesn't actually change much more. Somewhat random review and will be missing alot of points but just wanted to post.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Dont look at my play time I have played this game for hundreds of hours when i was a kid. This game is...amazing. Truly amazing. There are few words that are able to describe how crazy good this game is. No it does not have the depth of StarCraft, but its not designed to be a competitive game. Its a casual fun strategy, that you can play with you mouse. But dont let that turn you away from the game. There is plenty of challange for hardcore RTS fans like me. You can make the matchups very imbalanced, and there is not just one type of AI, there are 14 diferend adversaries, and no they are not just dificulties, they build their castels diferently, and use diferent types of army. There are historical campaings, but they are very underwhelming IMO.If i have to rate this game it would be a 9/10. If i have to trust the biast nostalgia 17/10 :). But a more realistic verdic would be 9/10. A must own for all self respecting RTS fans.NOW BEGONE FROM HERE GO PLAY THE GAME INFIDELS!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												This was the first game I ever bought for myself way back in 2002 and I've logged hundreds more hours in it than my steam profile would suggest. This game though over a decade old, is truly still relevant within the same castle building rts genre today and for me is more than just nostalgia. It combines a somewhat historically accurate and entertaining historical campaign following the rough lines of the First, Second and Third Crusades and playable from different sides of the conflicts. The AI can be rather easy to beat if exploited and with experience in beating the various AI lords you need to challenge yourself using the map maker and understanding AI play style to make winning the match a true challenge. I love this game and would recommend it to anyone with a historical inclination and an appreciation of rts games from the early 2000's. Hopefully someday they'll make a sequel worth playing.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Although, I haven't played this through Steam yet, this game is the greatest Medieval RTS game that there is. Besides the out dated graphics - if you're a veteran RTS player, you have probably played worse - this game is fantastic.This game was the first video game I really got into on the PC. I played countless hours, and if I had to make a guess, I'd say well over 2000+. Since September 2004, this game has stayed within my top 5 because it is simply just that good.I always find myself coming back to this game, year after year, never being dissapointed in the challenge that the computer opponents offer. When I played this game day in day out and finally mastered it, I could beat all 7 wolves on a team on my own. Now I don't play this game as much, but I still find myself going back to it, whenever a friend wants to play. Lets talk about what the game has to offer and compare to other games in it's series. Stronghold Crusader, many will say is the best in the entire series, and I'd have to agree. This game, is way cheaper, and rich with content, than it's sequel, Stronghold Crusader 2. Stronghold Crusader includes many different medieval units that you'd probably expect: Swordsman, Archers, Crossbowman, Knights on Horseback, Spearman, etc. But it includes many more like engineers, pikeman, macemen, horse archers, slaves, fire throwers... There are two types of troops: Arabic, or Crusader troops. Both similiar, yet both with their strengths and weaknesses. Some AI lords will use only Crusader troops, or only Arabic troops, while some will use a mixture of them both,Like I said before the AI can be pretty challenging. Of course, there are very, very stupid AI as well that you could beat no problem if you knew the very basics. But the Wolf, and Saladin are very challenging opponents that can take you hours to beat depending on the style of game you play. The campaign(s) are very challenging to beat and they offer you as little as possible to win...but you do get 3 chickens (passes) and once you beat a level you have already passed on, you get a chicken back. This game can be played with up to 8 players/AI lords. It can be free for all, 1v1, 4v4, 2v2v2v2, 5v3 or any combination of teams you want. Online or offline. Play with friends and players around the world easily on a program called GameRanger. It works well for me and my sister.The gameplay is a lot of fun, and not too complicated to understand. You have peasants that stay idle and are useless unless you provide jobs for them. Once you create say a woodcutters hut using the resources from your stockpile a peasant will walk his way to the hut and become a woodcutter. He will chop down the closest trees and deliver wood to your stockpile. You also need other resources like stone, iron, weapons, and most importantly, food. Without food, your peasants and workers will not want to stay at your castle, so they will leave. Make sure to keep the happiness/popularity above 50. Food, negative taxes, Ale/Inn, and large troop count will all be bonuses to popularity. If your king dies you lose. If all enemy kings are dead, you win :)To train troops, you need to use your resources to build buildings to produce troops. You can go 3 routes: Crusader troops, Arabic troops, or both. Barracks will be required to produce crusader troops. But crusader troops require weapons to be made so you need to make weapon workshops. Arabic troops need a mercenary post and hence the name cost more gold, but they do not require the time, money and resources for workshops to create weapons. Engineers, a more advanced unit, needs an Engineers guild to produce them. They can be helpful by taking castle walls down using catapults.There is also a free build mode, map editor, and custom scenario mode which offer even more fun with tha already addicting campaign, sandbox, and multiplayer modes.I highly recommend this game, and definitely if it is on sale. If you're debating over any other Stronghold game go for this one!10/10

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												I was only 5 years old, I loved Stronghold so much. I had all the merchandise and games. I pray to Stronghold everyday thanking it for the life i've been given. "Stronghold is love" I say "Stronghold is life". My dad hears me and says "Total War is better". I knew he was just jealous of my devotion for Stronghold. I called him a filthy peasant. He puts my granary on half rations and sends me to go to sleep. I'm crying now and my peasants are leaving. I lay in bed and its really cold. A warmth is moving towards me. I feel something touch me. Its the scribe, i'm so happy. He whispers in my ear "A message m'lord". He grabs me with his powerful scribe hands and puts me on my hands and knees. I'm ready. I open my gates for the scribe and he enters my castle. It hurts so much but I do it for the scribe. I can feel my castle tearing as my eyes start to water. I push against his force, I want to please the scribe. He roars a mighty roar as he fills my stockpile. My dad walks in. The scribe looks him straight in the eye and says "The stockpile is full m'lord". The scribe catapults out my window. "Stronghold is Love, Stronghold is life"

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												It was great in 2002, it's still great today. I may be slightly bias due to the fact that this game made up my childhood, but I feel all the positive comments are justified. The simplicity of this game is one of its many charms. Don't let this fool you, there is still plenty to do and this game can be adjusted to match your playstyle. Casual gamer? Try out a custom skirmish game where you make the rules. Looking for a challenge? Why not head to the Crusader Trials? Despite its simplicity, the game can surprise you at times. The AI is pretty impressive (unless you ask them to defend you; they aren't the brightest bulb in the bunch when it comes to that respect), the different strategies you can implement to obtain victory never ceases to amaze me. Forgive my bluntless, but I'm willing to say that this game is one of, if not the best, RTS games to date. I know it's my personal favourite (sorry Total War).

												Honestly this game, and the original Stronghold (HD) are some of the best, if not the best RTS games of their decade. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												It was great in 2002, it's still great today. I may be slightly bias due to the fact that this game made up my childhood, but I feel all the positive comments are justified. The simplicity of this game is one of its many charms. Don't let this fool you, there is still plenty to do and this game can be adjusted to match your playstyle. Casual gamer? Try out a custom skirmish game where you make the rules. Looking for a challenge? Why not head to the Crusader Trials? Despite its simplicity, the game can surprise you at times. The AI is pretty impressive (unless you ask them to defend you; they aren't the brightest bulb in the bunch when it comes to that respect), the different strategies you can implement to obtain victory never ceases to amaze me. Forgive my bluntless, but I'm willing to say that this game is one of, if not the best, RTS games to date. I know it's my personal favourite (sorry Total War).

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												A classic I loved to play as a kid along with the original. Don't let play hours fool you, I've played the cd version on and off since I first picked it up with my dad at EB games! (yup that long ago, EB games!!) A great and worthy sequel to the orginal!Pros-More awesome voiceovers, in arabic this time!-Good graphics for its time-Skirmish mode addon-New characters-Multiple campaigns-Arabic units-Desert theme-Same old game we love, they didn't ruin it, they didn't fix it either becase they didn't need to, it was perfect in its orignal release!-Historical missionsCons-The campaigns are less personal than the orginal, no big story that is, hearing the villians plot their schemes, or fireplace cutscenes, just some back story on the time and event and a massive campaign that is a string of skirmish missions put together, its still fun to beat though!OverallA game that has and will stand the test. Definitely better than the awful Strongholds 2 and 3. Firefly seriously just needs to go back to its roots and expand upon this game within the 3d engine, not change everything, and have better quality control!  I digress, get the original for its amazing story, and get this for its awesome skirmish mode!10/10      Classic Castle Building Sim

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												Imagine a real-time, fast-paced strategy game where you enter the Holy Lands following an unforgiving trail of fifty crusaders – each more difficult than the last; each with different enemies, different resources, different allies and different economies. You discover and master the art of defending and storming castles – planning your every move carefully while controlling armies of men, horses, portable-shields, catapults and more in the hundreds. Now, realize that the game in question, Stronghold Crusader, was released twelve years ago and that a succeeder is inbound Q4 2014.In comparison to the original Stronghold, Firefly Studios significantly altered the dynamics of Stronghold Crusader in an attempt to increase the game speed – which unforgivably means the first few minutes of each mission are crucial. The changes includes the addition of a range of Arabian mercenary units, where especially assassins, fire throwers and horse archers introduces a range of new opportunities upon both defending your own castle and conquering others. The traditional military units are still more powerful however, but takes significantly longer to recruit due to the extensive production line. The player must thus analyze the enemies and starting resources swiftly – the sooner the production line can be started, the better. Similar, if the enemies appear weak during the early stages, a quick and silent attack gently delivered by assassins might be preferred.One aspect is to defend your castle and attack enemies, a whole other layer of gameplay, which appears subtle at first glance, is the actual castle management. Stronghold Crusader introduces a range of buildings and techniques which allows the player to generate more money, extra powerful men or a harder working population, to name a few. Increasing your population’s happiness through religion or ale allows for higher taxes, crowding and even food shortages. Similar, increasing the amount of bad things (i.e. gallows, dunking tools or cesspits) in your castle makes your population work faster and thus generate a faster and more efficient money flow.Securing a food chain is even more important than it was in the original Stronghold due to the deserted and rocky terrain which greatly limits the amount of fertile areas. These areas are therefore both interesting and important strategic points; take out an enemy’s food supply and you force him out of his castle. The gameplay thus consists of both castle management, fighting and survival throughout 50 crusades, four chapters of historically inspired missions and an extra 30 crusades introduced after the original release – in total well above 40 hours of campaign gameplay, excluding later free- and custom-play.The RTS-genre has undeniably advanced significantly since the release of Stronghold Crusader on several fronts; including, but not limited to, the graphics (though, admittedly, the old graphics are charming), the audio, the interfaces and the AI. Especially the latter is easily noticeable if you have played any modern RTS-game – the AI in Stronghold Crusader is easily tricked, and once a player reaches a certain point in the map, winning ultimately becomes a matter of time due to the superior human player and the seemingly flat difficulty-level of the AIs. Instead, the game relies on quantity and starting perks such as six AIs with 20.000 gold each versus the player with only 3.000 gold. That said then the game unfortunately suffers from a range of bugs and glitches, which unavoidably results in quite some micromanagement of the player’s troops to ensure they indeed are doing the assigned task accordingly. The path-finding system has a tendency to chose some strange routes, and can, on rare occasions, end up getting your men stuck. Though, remembering the age of the game then these issues are minor and certainly not game breaking – merely frustrating due to the higher focus on micromanagement.The freedom in terms of building and designing your castle is intriguing and very unique compared to other RTS-games. Similar, the actual gameplay is extremely simple and straightforward, but due to the many layers of extra options and techniques during both fighting and castle management, the gameplay is yet challenging – and most importantly, fun. Ignoring the minor bugs and glitches, Stronghold Crusader is a solid game for any RTS-fan, and a great option for those who wishes to enter the genre!

number of helpful: 30 of 58 people (52%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												This review is not intended to address the original Stronghold Crusader, which is absolutely fantastic, but rather the HD version specifically.Also, Steam says I have almost no time on this at all. This is because I had to play it on Game Ranger and Steam did not record that time as playtime. I also put probably hundreds of hours into it before I bought it here.I have owned Stronghold Crusader for my entire adult life, and it was always one of my favorite games. When I saw that there was an HD version out, I immediately put it on my wishlist and eventually wound up owning it. Now, I have not taken seriously the idea that HD games are any better graphically than their original versions. I've played a few HD games and even in side by side pictures I have a hard time telling the difference. The main point to HD games, as far as I can tell, is that they are more playable on modern machines.While this game does technically run, it does so with difficulty. Generally windows behind the game bleed through somehow and cause disruption. Alt tabbing is possible but only with great disruption and it takes a good five to ten seconds to get back into the game. One nice thing about buying an old game on Steam is that you can usually have the Steam overlay and multiplayer with other steam users is quite easy. This game has no Steam overylay and multiplayer is actually extremely difficult. It took probably half an hour for two professional geeks to figure it out. That had a lot to do with us avoiding Game Ranger at all costs, but we couldn't find any other way to play it multiplayer. GameR anger it is.Now, I already owned this game. I have it on a compact disc downstairs. I got this game here because I thought it was something beyond the version from my late teens and would have some sort of advantage over that.Don't get me wrong. If you don't already own this game, do buy it. But not on Steam. Get it on Gog where you won't have all the drm. If you already own Stronghold Crusader, the HD version brings nothing new of any value.Again, I can't speak highly enough of Stronghold Crusader itself, but you don't need the HD version and you get none of the regular Steam advantages by buying it here.

												When it comes to gameplay, this is the best strategy game I have ever played. The economic system is brilliant, it is very realistic but at the same time simple and easy to understand. The castle and warfare mechanics are brilliant. There are numerous ways to build your castle and defend it, and a variety of options to defeat your enemies. While most strategy games tend to require the same tactics with just slight differences, this game takes strategical thinking to a whole new level. In fact, a game of SC is not that different from a game of chess. When it comes to graphics, of course, this is an old game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												What's that? No 3D-graphics? Well, guess what... It doesn't need that to be good!Here you are, starting only with some wood, stone and gold. You build - you recruit - you fight - you win (?). It's a simple concept and a lot of strategy games follow this direction. In fact, Stronghold Crusader isn't really complex, so the first sight might give you the impression of a boring city simulator... For me, there's something wonderful about this simplicity.The goal is to be the very best like no one ever was. Kill the enemy's king and get your well-earned peace while you defend your own crown-wearing buddy. Of course they won't invite you into their castle, so you have to invite yourself. In order to blast away their walls and towers, there are different ways, like hammering every single brick off the wall or dig a tunnel underneath it. They won't like you to be that rude, so they put archers on towers to keep your men away and you'll have to get rid of them first somehow! Either you ruin the towers with catapults or invade with own archers and fight back.This isn't what makes Stronghold Crusader so enjoyable. The true entertainment is the possibility to be a rotten ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to them! Every inhabitant of the castle is a free-walking NPC which can be killed too. It is incredibly annoying when your enemy has posted some archers beneath your farms and keeps killing your farmers. Not only is it very time consuming to fight off those archers, but it's also very stressful for the castle's economy. Every killed farmer means a lost delivery of food, and without food your people will get very angry. Your people start to leave your castle when you keep being such a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and soon you will only have three peasants left.If this is still too weak for you, you can step it up and use dirty tricks to wreck'em! If you manage to lit an enemy's building on fire, it will spread out drasticly, burning down every house 'n' human. This could lead to a total destruction of the castle, making them to start from the beginning. Fire is a great element of the game, because it can turn a lost-believed battle into a success.Otherwise I'd say it's a classic RTS. Build, fight and succeed. There are  singleplayer campaigns, but the true enjoyment is the multiplayer with friends, because of the nasty actions possible. Sadly you'll have to fiddle around with IPs and networks in order to connect to each other. Because this game doesn't require alot performance, the connection is always stable (at least for me it always was) and free of laggs. All I can say is that I've played this game for whole days years ago and I still enjoy this piece. The graphics may look very old and bad, but I think it only adds to the charisma the game shows.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												One of my favourite strategy games of all time. I played every Stronghold game they released and Stronghold Crusader is by far the best. It's an old game I can't deny that, but in my opinion the 2D graphics look more attractive than any other 3D from the other Stronghold Games. The only negative thing I can think of is that it's sometimes a little bit hard to handle, because there is no autosell/ autobuy option on the market. But All in All it is my favourite Stronghold game and maxbe the last good game they made

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Stronghold Crusader was a game I had played hundreds of hours of as a child. I remember playing it on an old windows 2000 machine. Like its predecessor Stronghold it is one of the best medieval strategy games on the market, and was revolutionary for its time. The game mechanics though older are superb and the campaign is worth playing through every scenario. Don't feel like fighting? Simply build a castle peacefully, and keep your people happy. The dynamicsOf the game rival most modern day strategy games. I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone who has played stronghold crusader before, and also to gamers looking for a well paced classic real time strategy game with a community that is still thriving to this day. I would definitely give it at the very least an 8/10 ifNot in my personal opinion a 10 out of 10.

												A game many played when they were younger and brings back memories, an RTS that has deep strategy which this game made even better through the desert setting and scarcer resources, and topped off by the fact that it's an RTS where I dont feel limited by my APM at all, and instead it's how I play the game rather than how fast I play it that merits reward. content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												This game is the GREATEST castle sim of all time. I started playing it long before steam was even a thing, and have loved it every minute since. This game offers several gamemodes, which with out just one, or one of them is even slightly altered, this game would be very different. The graphics are not the greatest, being created in the early 2000's, but that is beside the point. Some of the gamemodes include: Castle Building(Very Peaceful), Two Campaign trails(Begins Easy, becomes harder down the trail), Your 'average joe' multiplayer(Play against AI or even Players *Hard to play with other players)  You can create maps for multiplayer. You can 'relive' several great battles of the crusade. Many different types of units. If you buy this game, you receive Stronghold Crusader Extreme, which increases the amount of units, more AI, more campaign trails, and even more replay value. If you have not bought, you SHOULD buy it rightnow. I recommend this game, with a rating of 9.7/10

Posted: November 5, 2014
												If you have played this game and liked it, you will probably agree that this game is just a "QUIIIICK MARCH" away from becomming one of the most celebrated castle builders of the early 2000's.If you haven't tried it: I highly recommend this game for anyone who wants to get into the Stronghold franchise since it's the last game before the unnecessary micromanaging started, making you responsible for your citizens crap being placed in a pile rather than right in front of their door(I'm not kidding).Finally, if you have tried it didn't like it(or hated it), why did you bother reading this review?

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												Stronghold Crusader is a castle building simulator that combines warfare,economy and siege mecahnics .While original game had more focus on single player experiance this game replaces story telling with skirmish campaign .Overall this is improvment on the Stronghold 1 . It has new units,walls,characters and more responsive gameplay.Despite not having story this game is held up by the charismatic Lords whom you will fight through 50 crusader missions .One really cool thing about this game is the AI players . For artifical players they sure build interesting castles and can be pretty nasty opponents on hard diffeculty .Its near a perfect game which I consider a classic .

												I had played this years ago and had hit a wall IIRC, where one of the levels I kept losing to and gave up.  So it can be challenging.It can also be a little grindy if you haven't gone through the tutorial (me) and figured out all the different units and maybe some more combined arms strategy.  ==It gets very grindy.==Basically this is Age of Empires or others from that RTS genre and timeframe, but this emphasizes the happiness mechanic by allowing bribing or taxing the people and feeding or starving them, along with other buildings that might affect happiness or fear and productivity.  Of couse once you understand the new mechanic, it's not too interesting - it translates into more buttons to push and wanting some manager to handle all that - but this is an old game.  They hadn't invented managers yet.Note: A key difference from Age of Empires is that in Stronghold, if you have enough resources for <whatever>, purchasing that creates it _instantaneously_.  There's no wait for units to churn out or buildings to build - they are there the moment you click the build button.I'm on the 6th or so level in the campain, and I have yet to build a decent "castle-looking" castle.  It all becomes more like a tower defense game in that regard.Voice acting is excellent, though not too varied.  There's some nice cuteness there I really like the archers and the when the knight complains if you ask him to walk all over the continent!  Hahaha :)ALSO nice surprise was the inclusion of a Stronghold Crusader "Extreme" add-on, which I'd never heard of until I downloaded the game.  It's apparently a set of new scenarios.

												I grew up playing this game. From the time I was 6, I was already done with the Historical Campaign and the Crusader Missions. But then, around when I was 10, I let my friend borrow it. This was a mistake. He lost it less than a day after I gave it to him. I was so disappointed. I checked Wal-Marts, GameStop... I wanted that game back so badly! I was so desperate ot find a way to get it back. Then, it hit me; Steam is a place for (almost) all games! I searched up, "Stronghold Crusader" and was shocked to find out there was even more Crusaders  to be offered! I got a $20 Steam Card and purchased 2 Stronghold Crusader games. I got one for my self, and the other for my friend, Ethan. We enjoy playing it!

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Stronghold Crusader had the best gameplay in the entire series, but the graphics were getting a little bit outdated after a decade. This HD re-release makes it look good enough to last another decade. Don't expect fancy 3D graphics, this is old-school isometric 2.5D.The gameplay is solid. There are tutorials to teach you the basics and there are two "crusader trails" with about 50 missions each to give you a lot of different scenarios to play through. There are also campaigns with a story to them. You play as a lord in the time of the crusades. You start with a small manor and a hand full of troops and there are enemies who want you dead. Build farms to grow food to keep your population alive. Gather resources such as wood, stone and metal. Build up a castle wall-by-wall according to your own design. Put down towers of different shapes and sizes: small tall towers to give your archers extra range, and big lower towers on which you can mount siege weapons. Have your population craft weapons to train soldiers or hire mercenaries with gold. Then try to invade your enemies' castles. Build catapults to destroy their walls, or use siege ladders to get your archers on their walls to turn their safe castle into a slaughterhouse. Beware of hidden traps like spike pits and burning oil.Skirmish mode allows you to pick from a few dozen maps, some balanced and some unbalanced. Want to play 4 vs 4 on a balanced map? Want a real challenge, then pick an unbalanced map and stack the odds against you. The AI does not have traditional difficulty levels, but there are a number of AI personalities that have their own strategy. Fighting against the Caliph means you have to be prepared dirty tricks like waves of slaves trying to burn down your farms, and fire arrow archers trying to set the ground on fire when you try to take his castle. King Richard attacks with honor and superior force using siege weapons and heavily armored units. The Sultan is a dreamer who focuses more on building an economy than training a superior army. The Snake thows large numbers of archers and spearmen at you, favoring quantity over quality.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												This game is one of my all time favorites. The music was so well made and beautiful that have them in my song library. I have 200+ hours in this one and its not just because im a die-hard fan (though i am), there are 95+ missions in game with a good amount of AI with varying difficulty. Also includes a map editor for you to make your own maps and seige missions. If new to stronghold, it has a realistic economic system for your castle to thrive (ex.- need crossbow men? frist you need a cow farm, then a tanner who takes the cows for the hide armor, then you need the crossbow its self to be made from a flecher and both craftables placed in the armory). This game is an absolute gem. 10/10

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												First off, the game is great. There's no denying that. But is this version worth buying? It requires third party software to be played online, it's not compatible with the steam overlay, it's basically the same thing you might get from GOG, except it automatically installs gameranger without even letting you choose any of the options.Both GOG and steam are the same version, except one has to be downloaded through a client, and the other only uses an un-intrusive installer. Get the GOG, or hell, even pirate it, and you'll get the same thing. Basically don't expect anything re-vamped like in other HD remakes, all you get is the possibility of running the same old game at with a higher resolutions.It's your choice if you want to buy it on steam either way, but I'd recommend to try elsewhere.

content:
Posted: March 19
												Alright! Much better than the Stronghold HD which I consider totally awful for it's terrible graphics. Despite Crusader HD being not much different at the first look, this one has much nicer graphics which gives a reason enough to stay a little longer and actually learn to play some, a little obscure user interface still being a slight problem. It'd be nice that basic management tools for user interface would be more obvious for those less frequent players of the game, like the management of the game view and the required actions from player would be nice to have in text on screen in the early stages and optionally even later on. SimCity 4 is the best example of a game from this era that guides a novice through the tutorials to give a good head start to the game and keeps palyer in its thight grip further the game continues. Will likely give Crusader a proper chance at some point.Addendum: the Stonghold Crusader Extreme HD side product didn't seem as interesting as I was looking for just a builder game. It too has a building side to it, but the game itself is intended for more action driven multiplayer sessions. Also the map builder had some glitchy graphics to it that I found alienating which I didn't recognise in the main game. Have I bought SCE HD alone would have been much disappointed, but now it just takes a little extra space on my disk unless I decide to doze it. Do you still find active servers for this old game, beats me, but if you're into that kind of stuff you'll probably seek company to make it happen.

content:
Posted: February 19
												If you love this series already, go for it. The HD version makes those old graphics truly enjoyable to play on modern screens, and you already know the rest. My lack of recommendation comes from the perspective of someone who enjoys old RTS games, but had never played anything in this series. Stronghold Crusader has great concepts such as the economy and popularity systems. I'm guessing those features, innovative for their time and still rare in later games, are among the reasons this game garnered such a huge following. However, the UI and combat are stuck in the mid-90s era of clunkiness and extreme simplicity, and I for one simply can't get past those shortcomings.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Back in its days, it used to be a good game; good fun, smart games - the Stronghold series marked an important step in the evolution of the genre. Take it from someone who is old enough to have played the first Stronghold back when it was published.However, what I'm asked to review here is not the Crusader that came out many years ago; it is instead the HD Steam version.If you already own the original game, this won't offer you anything more.If you have never played it before, you might not appreciate it, because time has not been kind to it, and the HD title is quite misguiding: while it may be true that the game will start on a widescreen and on high resolutions without making your PC explode, it is also true that once you are playing it, the difference in definition from the original is basically non-existant.Considering that it is a milestone and it comes really cheap, especially on sale, it might be worth giving a try; however, history never turns back, and you will never appreciate it as much as you would have back when it was brand new.
